identity.ic_name: National Cancer Institute

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Finding and obtaining NCI-supported datasets, software, and tools across various cancer research areas.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Catalog contains links to over 200 NCI-supported research tools, databases, and services. Most resources are free and open, but some detailed data require controlled access.

identity.resource_name: Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) Program
identity.ic_name: National Cancer Institute

access_cost.access_model: Open Access (Web Tools/Aggregate Data); Controlled Access (Research Data Files)

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Analyzing cancer incidence and survival trends by age, sex, race, and geographic area; informing public health planning.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Comprehensive cancer statistics database. Publicly accessible via web tools. Researchers can request detailed research data files at no cost.

identity.ic_name: National Cancer Institute

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Hosting, standardization, and analysis of large-scale cancer genomic and clinical data (e.g., TCGA, TARGET).

lifecycle_curation.notes: Platform for cancer genomics data. Open access for summary data; controlled access for detailed data requires dbGaP authorization (no fee). Provides harmonization and analysis tools.

identity.ic_name: National Cancer Institute

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Browsing and downloading de-identified radiology and pathology images for cancer research (e.g., LIDC, CPTAC data).

lifecycle_curation.notes: Archive of de-identified radiology and pathology images for cancer. Publicly available with optional registration for most data.

identity.ic_name: National Cancer Institute

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Visualizing geographic patterns of cancer burden, risk factors, and screening across different population subgroups; informing policy and research opportunities.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Interactive GIS-based tools to visualize cancer statistics by state, county, demographics, and risk factors. Open to the public online for custom maps, graphs, and data downloads. Includes the interactive Cancer Atlas views within the State Cancer Profiles platform.

identity.ic_name: National Cancer Institute

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Finding and implementing rigorously evaluated cancer control interventions (e.g., for tobacco control, screening, or diet/nutrition).

lifecycle_curation.notes: Searchable database of rigorously evaluated cancer control interventions. Freely available for program planners to find intervention summaries, materials, and publications.

identity.ic_name: National Cancer Institute

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Collecting self-administered 24-hour dietary recalls for epidemiologic, behavioral, or clinical nutrition research.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Web-based dietary recall platform provided by NCI; researchers register projects and manage respondent-facing surveys.

identity.ic_name: National Cancer Institute

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Capturing detailed 24-hour time-use and activity recalls for studies of physical activity, sedentary time, and energy expenditure.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Companion to ASA24 focused on activity and time-use diaries; investigators configure studies and respondents complete browser-based recalls.

identity.ic_name: National Cancer Institute

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Finding resources and knowledge to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of collaborative, team-based science initiatives.

lifecycle_curation.notes: An NCI-hosted portal of user-generated and community-curated resources to support team-based science (SciTS).

identity.ic_name: National Cancer Institute

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Searching for and downloading standardized behavioral and social science measures (surveys, scales) organized by theoretical construct; contributing to measure standardization.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Interactive website for sharing standardized behavioral and social science measures. Free to use; login required to contribute data.

identity.ic_name: National Cancer Institute

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Freely using comprehensive biomedical terminology (for oncology, genetics, etc.) for coding, annotating data, and facilitating semantic interoperability.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Core reference terminology and biomedical ontology. Provided under open license for coding and annotating data.

identity.ic_name: National Eye Institute

target_populations: Patients with Inherited Ocular Conditions (30+ diseases)

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Requesting de-identified data and associated genetic samples for studies on inherited ocular conditions; research on genotype-phenotype correlations.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NEI's data repository and biospecimen registry for inherited eye diseases. Free for qualified researchers upon approval of a research proposal and data use agreement.

identity.ic_name: National Eye Institute

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Integrated gene expression and multi-omic data analysis for eye tissues (e.g., via eyeIntegration, PLAE).

lifecycle_curation.notes: Suite of NEI-supported data portals (e.g., eyeIntegration) providing integrated data, visualization, and analysis tools for ocular research.

identity.ic_name: National Eye Institute

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Analyzing retinal imaging data obtained from adaptive optics systems for individual nerve cell resolution and function measurement.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Open-source software from the NEI Adaptive Optics research program for retinal imaging data analysis. Available to download without cost.

identity.ic_name: National Eye Institute

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Evaluating the impact of mutations on protein structure for eye-relevant genes; analyzing protein changes related to genetic eye diseases.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Provides computational tools to evaluate mutation impacts on protein structure, based on protein modeling and mutagenesis simulations. Openly available.

identity.ic_name: National Eye Institute

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing publicly shared datasets and analysis code from NEI AGI projects (e.g., AMD Integrative Biology, single-cell eye atlas) to study vision restoration and regeneration.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Various NEI AGI projects share data and code through Data Commons and project websites. Free public access to accelerate vision research.

identity.ic_name: National Eye Institute

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Measuring the self-reported vision-targeted health status and quality of life in chronic eye disease research and clinical practice.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Validated 25-item survey instrument for vision-related quality of life. Freely provided for research use, often available for download in multiple languages.

identity.ic_name: National Eye Institute

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing and comparing gene expression and sequence data for various eye tissues and animal models.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Genomics resource hosting gene expression and sequence data for eye tissues and animal models. Publicly accessible.

identity.ic_name: National Eye Institute

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Obtaining biospecimens (DNA, cell lines) and clinical data from patients with inherited eye diseases to study genetic causes.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Banks DNA and clinical data from patients with inherited eye diseases. Approved researchers can obtain biospecimens at no cost (may pay shipping/minimal fees) for genetic studies.

identity.ic_name: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing individual-level data and biospecimens from major NHLBI studies (e.g., Framingham, CARDIA) for secondary analysis to drive new discoveries.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Central repository for clinical trial and epidemiological study data and biospecimens. Requires a brief proposal and Data Use Agreement for controlled access, but no fees are charged. Open-access subsets are available.

identity.ic_name: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute

domains: Heart, Lung, Blood, and Sleep (HLBS) Disorders

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Securely storing, cross-linking, and analyzing large-scale genomic, clinical, and imaging datasets (e.g., TOPMed) in a cloud environment.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Cloud-based platform with tools and workflows for analyzing NHLBI datasets. No platform fee; controlled data requires eRA Commons and dbGaP approval. Users may incur cloud provider costs, but NIH often subsidizes with STRIDES credits.

identity.ic_name: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute

domains: Heart, Lung, Blood, and Sleep (HLBS) Disorders

access_cost.cost_status: Free (platform access); cloud compute billed via STRIDES credits

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Provision and orchestration layer that lets researchers stage, transform, and analyze NHLBI BioData Catalyst datasets in secure workspaces.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Data STAGE is the shared storage and tooling environment that powers BioData Catalyst workspaces and services.

identity.ic_name: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing controlled-access human genetic and phenotypic data (including NHLBI TOPMed datasets) for secondary analysis.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Maintained by NLM (NCBI), but houses numerous NHLBI-funded genomic datasets (e.g., TOPMed). Free access for controlled data requires NIH eRA Commons account and Data Access Committee (DAC) approval.

identity.ic_name: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute

domains: Heart, Lung, Blood, and Sleep (HLBS) Disorders

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Downloading publicly available data summaries or limited datasets from long-term NHLBI cohort studies (e.g., Framingham, Jackson Heart Study) for secondary analysis or teaching.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Public data summaries or limited datasets released from long-term NHLBI cohort studies (e.g., Framingham, Jackson Heart Study). Freely accessible for public use. Landing hub highlighting major NHLBI-funded cohort studies and public data releases.

identity.ic_name: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute

domains: Heart, Lung, Blood, and Sleep (HLBS) Disorders

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Immediate download and analysis of publicly available subsets of de-identified study data from major NHLBI studies (e.g., for preliminary analysis or teaching).

lifecycle_curation.notes: A subset of datasets within the BioLINCC repository that are designated 'open access' and can be downloaded instantly without the need for committee approval.

identity.ic_name: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Utilizing standardized tools (like Study Quality Assessment Tools) and documents (like CDEs and manuals from networks such as PETAL) to design and conduct rigorous clinical research.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Provides free resources for clinical researchers, such as common data elements (CDEs), clinical trial manuals and protocols (e.g., PETAL Network), and quality assessment tools. Publicly accessible and downloadable.

identity.resource_name: AnVIL (Genomic Data Science Analysis, Visualization, and Informatics Lab-space)
identity.ic_name: National Human Genome Research Institute

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing and analyzing large-scale genomic datasets (e.g., 1000 Genomes, GTEx) in a secure, compliant cloud environment.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NHGRI's cloud-based platform for genomic data sharing and analysis. Free to access (no platform fee); users incur cloud provider costs which are often subsidized by NIH STRIDES.

identity.ic_name: National Human Genome Research Institute

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Searching for and downloading published Genome-Wide Association Study (GWAS) findings and summary statistics.

lifecycle_curation.notes: A public database of published GWAS findings, jointly maintained by NHGRI and Europe's EMBL-EBI. Open access: researchers can search and download GWAS results (trait-variant associations) at no cost.

identity.ic_name: National Human Genome Research Institute

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Curating and providing consensus interpretations of clinically relevant genes and variants to improve genetic testing and clinical practice.

lifecycle_curation.notes: An NHGRI-funded open resource that curates clinically relevant genes and variants. Provides a free searchable database of gene-disease validity classifications and variant pathogenicity interpretations.

identity.ic_name: National Human Genome Research Institute

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing large functional genomics datasets (Encyclopedia of DNA Elements) for analyzing gene regulatory mechanisms and non-coding DNA.

lifecycle_curation.notes: A repository from the NHGRI-led ENCODE project containing large functional genomics datasets. Freely accessible: all ENCODE data can be browsed or downloaded without restriction.

identity.ic_name: National Human Genome Research Institute

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Serving as the definitive reference genome assembly for aligning sequencing reads and annotating genetic variations in human research.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NHGRI supports the maintenance of the human reference genome. Distributed openly via NCBI/ENA/UCSC Genome Browser, free of charge.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Aging

access_cost.access_model: Open Access (Public Use); Controlled Access (Restricted Data)

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Analyzing long-term trends in health, economic status, and aging processes in a large American cohort.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Longitudinal study of over 20,000 Americans over age 50. Public-use datasets are freely available (registration required); restricted data is also available at no charge under agreements.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Aging

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing centralized clinical and neuropathological data from NIA-funded Alzheimer's Disease Research Centers for analysis.

lifecycle_curation.notes: A centralized repository of clinical and neuropathological data from NIA-funded Alzheimer's Disease Research Centers. Free for investigators after review and DUA.

identity.resource_name: NIAGADS (NIA Genetics of Alzheimer's Disease Data Storage Site)
identity.ic_name: National Institute on Aging

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing and analyzing genetic and omics data for Alzheimer's and related dementias for discovery and variant analysis.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIA's genetics data repository for Alzheimer's and related dementias. Data are provided through secure download for free after application. Also offers an open-access genomics database portal for summary statistics.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Aging

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing multimodal longitudinal data to study disease progression, identify biomarkers, and validate imaging techniques for Alzheimer's disease.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Provides a vast collection of longitudinal MRI/PET images, clinical assessments, and CSF/blood biomarkers. Data are openly shared with researchers worldwide—registration and DUA are required, but no fee.

identity.resource_name: National Health and Aging Trends Study (NHATS)
identity.ic_name: National Institute on Aging

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Studying disability, caregiving, and health trajectories among older U.S. Medicare beneficiaries using annual longitudinal surveys.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NHATS provides annual data files (with linked caregiver surveys) for qualified researchers via the NHATS website and ICPSR after completing a data use agreement.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Aging

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Analyzing nationally representative midlife cohort data that link psychosocial measures with biomarkers and cognitive testing.

lifecycle_curation.notes: MIDUS study waves (including biomarker projects) are distributed through ICPSR with free registration and signed data use terms.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Aging

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Requesting access to the nation’s longest-running study of human aging for analyses of clinical, imaging, and biomarker trajectories.

lifecycle_curation.notes: BLSA data access is granted through NIA upon submission of a data request and approved analysis plan.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Aging

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing and integrating complex behavioral, cognitive, and molecular data from NIA-funded projects through the NIH data archive ecosystem.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIA utilizes NIH data archives (NDA/NIMH) for sharing behavioral and cognitive data and AMP-AD multi-omic data. These platforms allow no-cost access to deposited datasets after application.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Aging

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Obtaining cell lines from the Aging Cell Repository (Coriell) or aged mice/rats for studies on aging mechanisms and longevity.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIA provides research resources like the Aging Cell Repository and Aged Rodent Colonies. Cell lines and animals are typically provided free of charge, with researchers often only paying for shipping/minimal fees.

identity.resource_name: NIA Data Sharing Resources for Researchers
identity.ic_name: National Institute on Aging

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Obtaining free guidance, policy information, and templates for creating data management and sharing plans in compliance with NIH policies.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIA offers free guidance and tools (policies, templates) for researchers to share and manage data, aiming to make aging research data more FAIR.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Querying and downloading detailed information on U.S. alcohol laws and policies (e.g., state laws on underage drinking, taxation) for policy research and public health studies.

lifecycle_curation.notes: A comprehensive database of alcohol-related laws and policies in the U.S. Fully open-access: users can query and download policy datasets without registration or fees.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Secondary analysis of human subjects data from completed NIAAA-funded clinical trials and epidemiological studies on alcohol use and addiction.

lifecycle_curation.notes: A repository for human subjects data from NIAAA-funded studies, integrated within the NIMH Data Archive infrastructure. Free access for qualified researchers after creating an account and requesting data.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Obtaining and analyzing legacy NIAAA datasets (e.g., NESARC) for public use and secondary analysis of alcohol consumption and related outcomes.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Legacy datasets from completed NIAAA clinical trials and epidemiological surveys (e.g., NESARC) are often shared via public-use archives (like ICPSR) at no cost to researchers.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Using freely downloadable forms and guidelines (e.g., DSMC templates, assessment forms, GCP resources) to enhance the quality and safety of alcohol clinical trials.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIAAA's Clinical Research Toolkit provides freely downloadable templates, manuals, and guidelines for investigators running alcohol trials (e.g., assessment forms, DSMC templates). This 'toolbox' is free to access.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing public data on trends in alcohol consumption and outcomes (e.g., Surveillance Reports) and evidence-based interventions (e.g., College Drinking Prevention curriculum).

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIAAA's public databases like Alcohol Epidemiologic Data System reports, Surveillance Reports, and College Drinking Prevention curriculum are all offered as free resources for researchers and community stakeholders.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Obtaining NIAAA-supported research reagents (e.g., animal models of alcohol metabolism) for use in basic and translational alcohol research studies.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Through NIAAA-supported Alcohol Research Resource centers, investigators can obtain certain research reagents (e.g., recombinant enzymes, animal models) at no cost, often just requiring a Material Transfer Agreement.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing and reusing clinical and mechanistic data from NIAID-funded immunology and infectious disease studies; performing in-portal data analysis.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIAID's flagship data-sharing repository for immunology and infectious disease research. Completely free; users register to browse and download datasets (subject to human data approval) and use built-in analysis tools.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Searching for known epitopes by pathogen or disease; using integrated epitope prediction algorithms for vaccine development.

lifecycle_curation.notes: An NIAID-supported open database of antibody and T-cell epitopes. Freely available online; no login required for searches/downloads, and includes integrated analysis tools.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Obtaining research-grade biological materials, including biodefense and emerging disease agents, for infectious disease studies.

lifecycle_curation.notes: A NIAID-sponsored center distributing reagents for microbiology and infectious disease research. Materials are provided at no cost to academia/nonprofits; users must register and be approved for bio-safety compliance.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Interrogate integrated omics datasets for parasites, vectors, and related pathogens with built-in comparative and visualization tools.

lifecycle_curation.notes: VEuPathDB aggregates multiple eukaryotic pathogen resources (e.g., PlasmoDB, AmoebaDB) funded by NIAID and provides unified query and analysis workflows.

identity.resource_name: Bacterial and Viral Bioinformatics Resource Center (BV-BRC)
identity.ic_name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Manage bacterial and viral genome projects, run annotation pipelines, and share Jupyter-based analyses through the BV-BRC workspace.

lifecycle_curation.notes: BV-BRC merges the former PATRIC and IRD/ViPR resources into a single NIAID-funded platform for bacterial and viral pathogens.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Download curated HIV sequence alignments and use specialized tools for vaccine and diagnostics research.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Operated by Los Alamos National Laboratory with NIAID support; includes HIV, HCV, and TB sequence resources.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

access_cost.access_model: Open Access (Subject to Terms of Use)

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Performing secondary analysis of de-identified data from completed clinical trials focused on HIV/AIDS and infectious diseases (e.g., ACTG, HPTN networks).

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIAID shares de-identified DMID/DAIDS-sponsored clinical trial data packages; investigators follow the posted process to request access and agree to the data-use policy.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing standardized protocols for specific research areas (e.g., allergen research via ASP, microbial research via EMME) and toxicology test methods/data.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Provides no-cost research tools such as ASP Resource Portal (allergen protocols), ICCVAM-NICEATM (toxicology data), and EMME (microbial research protocols).

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Using tools like NetMHC for predicting T-cell epitopes, analyzing influenza virus data via FluDB, and determining HLA types for research studies.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIAID supports development of free bioinformatics tools like Epitope Prediction tools (NetMHC, via IEDB) and FluDB (influenza research database) with free analysis interfaces.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing multimodal data to study osteoarthritis progression, risk factors, and imaging biomarkers.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Large NIAMS-supported longitudinal study of knee OA. All data are freely available, but require registration and DUA.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Obtaining cell lines, DNA, and associated clinical data for studies on autoimmune and musculoskeletal disorders (e.g., Lupus Family Registry).

lifecycle_curation.notes: Repositories for diseases like lupus. Approved investigators can obtain specimens/data at no cost (may pay shipping).

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing clinical data from intramural natural history studies and external consortia (e.g., IMACS) for disease analysis.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Data from intramural studies and IMACS. Shared via collaboration or request without charge. Includes resources such as the International Myositis Assessment and Clinical Studies Group (IMACS) database.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Obtaining specialized mouse strains (e.g., arthritis models) for studies on musculoskeletal disease mechanisms.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Jackson Laboratory Repository distributes strains. Models provided at minimal cost (shipping only) to academic users.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Discovering and accessing NIAMS-relevant data hosted on NIH Common Fund resources and large external repositories (e.g., FaceBase, dbGaP).

lifecycle_curation.notes: Index to NIAMS-co-sponsored resources (FaceBase, Metabolomics Workbench) and public databases (dbGaP).

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Utilizing standardized pain/function questionnaires and free patient education handouts/toolkits for studies and clinical practice.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Free online toolkits ('Handout on Health') and standardized questionnaires (e.g., pain scales) for free reuse.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing and analyzing critical care patient data (MIMIC) and physiological waveforms for algorithm development and research.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Repository of physiological signals and clinical databases (MIMIC). Most data is open access; sensitive data (MIMIC) requires DUA but is free.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Downloading ready-to-print anatomical, molecular, or lab equipment models; creating custom models from protein/imaging data.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Online portal for sharing 3D-printable models. Completely free to download models; no login is needed.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Developing custom applications for image segmentation, registration, and analysis in medical imaging research.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Open-source software library for medical image processing. Freely available under a permissive license.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Quantifying and analyzing biomedical images (e.g., microscopy, gels) using an open-source, public domain platform.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Widely-used image analysis software (evolved from original NIH Image). Public domain and free to download/use for any purpose.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Finding and submitting standardized data on nanoparticle characteristics and their biological/environmental effects.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Database cataloging biological and environmental interactions of nanomaterials. Open resource, free to access and use.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing information, protocols, and reference datasets for the evaluation and validation of point-of-care diagnostic devices.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Provides information/protocols for point-of-care diagnostic devices. Shared knowledge base/datasets are freely accessible.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Utilizing specialized open-source software (e.g., FEBio) for finite element modeling and simulation in biomedical research.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIBIB manages open-source algorithms and software (e.g., FEBio for biomechanics). Free to download.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Obtaining large, anonymized imaging datasets from NIH Clinical Centers for training and testing machine learning algorithms (e.g., for tumor segmentation).

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIBIB sponsors challenges where data are anonymized and shared openly at no cost.

identity.ic_name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing de-identified data and requesting biospecimens from dozens of NICHD-funded maternal/child health studies for secondary analysis.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Centralized NIH-approved repository for data and biospecimens. No-cost access is provided after online request and approval.

identity.resource_name: Maternal and Pediatric Precision in Therapeutics (MPRINT) Hub
identity.ic_name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Finding pharmacokinetic data and simulation models focused on pregnancy, lactation, and pediatric drug dosing.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Hub aggregating data, models, and knowledge in maternal/fetal and pediatric pharmacology. Freely available and funded to be an open resource.

identity.ic_name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Secondary analysis of long-term studies like Fragile Families and the Stillbirth Collaborative Research Network (SCRN).

lifecycle_curation.notes: Data from cohorts like Fragile Families and SCRN are made publicly accessible or available on request at no cost.

identity.ic_name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing autism and related developmental data from NICHD-funded studies housed in the NIH Data Archive (NDA).

lifecycle_curation.notes: NICHD contributes to centralized platforms like the NIH Data Archive (NDA) for autism data (NDAR). Access is free for qualified researchers.

identity.ic_name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Obtaining model organisms (zebrafish mutant lines, mouse ES cells) for developmental biology and pediatric disease modeling.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Supports centers that distribute models (e.g., Zebrafish Center). Models provided at no charge (requesters usually only pay minimal shipping/handling).

identity.ic_name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Downloading and using validated instruments (e.g., developmental screening tools) for free in research protocols.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NICHD makes various validated instruments available at no cost (e.g., Adolescent Sexual Behavior Assessment) for free download.

identity.ic_name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Adopting standardized definitions (CDEs) in study protocols to harmonize data collection across pediatric research studies.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NICHD helped develop CDEs for pediatric research (e.g., neonatal ICU outcomes). These CDEs are shared on the NIH CDE Repository and are free to use.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Querying integrated audiology, genetic, and imaging data to study genotype-phenotype correlations in pediatric hearing loss.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Database integrating clinical audiology/genetic data for children with hearing loss. Accessible at no cost to qualified researchers (requires application/approval to protect privacy).

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing speech samples and transcripts to study fluency development, stuttering, or perform linguistic analysis.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Shared database focused on stuttering, part of the TalkBank system. Data sets and associated software (CLAN) are free to access for research/education (requires free TalkBank account and terms agreement).

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing recorded narratives and test scores to study language production, rehabilitation, and linguistic patterns in aphasia.

lifecycle_curation.notes: TalkBank repository housing language samples from individuals with aphasia. Researchers and clinicians can access the data for free with a free TalkBank account.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Discovering and accessing large, publicly available datasets (like NHANES) relevant to communication disorders epidemiology and population health.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Curated list of publicly available databases relevant to NIDCD mission areas. Linked external databases (e.g., NHANES) are generally open access and free.

identity.resource_name: NIDCD-funded Genetic Resource (Hereditary Hearing Loss Homepage)
identity.ic_name: National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Investigating known gene localizations and mutations for monogenic nonsyndromic hearing impairment.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Supports resources like the Hereditary Hearing Loss Homepage. Databases are openly accessible with no login or payment required.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Obtaining unique animal models (e.g., mouse vestibular mutants, ferret models of hearing loss) for research on communication disorders.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIDCD-sponsored models are shared through repositories like The Jackson Laboratory. Typically available to academic researchers for free or minimal cost (shipping only).

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Downloading and using standardized, validated questionnaires for outcome measurement in clinical trials and research studies.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Shares evaluation tools (e.g., Tinnitus Functional Index) that are free for clinical researchers to download and use (public domain or distributed with permission).

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Searching and downloading extensive datasets on craniofacial development and disorders; using the integrated 3D visualization tools.

lifecycle_curation.notes: A NIDCR-funded data repository and hub for craniofacial research. It's freely accessible (FAIR data principles); requires a simple account registration (no fee).

identity.resource_name: Human Salivary Proteome and Microbiome Databases
identity.ic_name: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing standardized data on the human salivary proteome and oral microbiome for biomarker discovery and disease mechanism studies.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Data resulting from NIDCR-supported efforts (e.g., salivary proteome) are available in public databases (like Salivaomics Knowledge Base) for free.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing genomic data for cleft lip/palate, dentinogenesis imperfecta (via dbGaP), and querying the Craniofacial Gene Ontology (Craneo).

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIDCR contributes genomic data (e.g., cleft lip/palate genetics) to dbGaP. Also co-funds Craniofacial Gene Ontology (Craneo) which is openly accessible.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Secondary analysis of large datasets (e.g., OPPERA) on TMD pain to pursue new hypotheses about chronic pain mechanisms.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Large datasets on temporomandibular disorder (TMD) pain, including genetic and psychological data (OPPERA study). Available for sharing via NIDCR or dbGaP at no cost.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Using the 3D Facial Landmarking Tool on external image data or exploring craniofacial developmental genes via the Genome Browser.

lifecycle_curation.notes: FaceBase provides free utilities like a 3D Facial Landmarking Tool and an interactive Genome Browser. The API allows programmatic access without fees or restrictions.

identity.resource_name: NIDCR Repository of Regenerative Dental Medicine Data
identity.ic_name: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing data from trials and projects in dental tissue engineering (e.g., tooth regeneration, biomaterials) for replication or secondary analysis.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Data from regenerative dental medicine trials are encouraged to be deposited in free or NIH-funded general repositories for open access.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing key public datasets (e.g., CDC's National Oral Health Surveillance System) for dental public health and epidemiological studies.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIDCR points researchers to important external open-access datasets (e.g., CDC's National Oral Health Surveillance System, MEPS dental data). NIDCR sometimes compiles these into user-friendly formats for free.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Generating resources like consensus diagnostic criteria (for periodontal diseases) and classification images to improve research consistency and training.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Generates resources such as consensus diagnostic criteria (e.g., for periodontal diseases) and makes them openly available to improve research consistency.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Requesting datasets and/or samples from major NIDDK trials (e.g., DPP, EDIC, CRIC) for secondary analysis to test new hypotheses.

lifecycle_curation.notes: A comprehensive repository for data and biospecimens from NIDDK-funded studies. No-cost access; controlled data requires a proposal and DUA.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Instantly downloading summary data or trial metadata from NIDDK studies for preliminary analysis, teaching, or non-committee review.

lifecycle_curation.notes: A subset of datasets in the NIDDK Central Repository designated for immediate download (no proposal needed) after a simple click-through agreement.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Discovering data, tools, animal models, and antibodies relevant to diabetes, kidney, and digestive diseases; locating specific omics datasets via the DKOMICS catalog.

lifecycle_curation.notes: An open online portal that helps researchers discover data, tools, and resources across the NIDDK domain. Free to use as a search engine and database aggregator.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing and performing secondary analysis on data from large NIDDK-funded clinical trials (e.g., TrialNet, TONIC) which are shared via public repositories.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIDDK ensures data from its large clinical trials are shared (e.g., TrialNet, TONIC) and deposited in the NIDDK-CR or another NIH repository, made available at no cost to requesters.

identity.resource_name: Genetic and Genomic Databases (T1DBase, Atlas of GI Motility)
identity.ic_name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Analyzing T1D genetics and genomics (T1DBase) or accessing beta cell biology data and histology images from consortia.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIDDK has facilitated free access to various genetic databases, including T1DBase (Type 1 Diabetes Base) and data portals from consortia (e.g., Beta Cell Biology Consortium).

identity.resource_name: APOL1 Long-term Kidney Transplantation Outcomes Network (APOLLO)
identity.ic_name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Studying the impact of APOL1 gene variants on long-term kidney transplant outcomes.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIDDK's APOLLO study will share data on the impact of APOL1 gene variants in kidney transplant; data are planned to be available via NIH repositories at no cost to researchers.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Obtaining biosamples (serum, tissue) from completed studies (e.g., DPP, CRIC) for use in new laboratory-based studies.

lifecycle_curation.notes: The NIDDK Central Repository's biospecimen bank provides research biosamples from completed studies. Investigators can request these samples for free (may pay shipping/IRB costs).

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Using tools like the Pediatric Z-Score Calculator for growth metrics, Body Weight Planner, or CRISP kidney pathology scoring software for clinical and research purposes.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIDDK develops or funds many free software and analysis tools (e.g., Pediatric Z-Score Calculator, CRISP kidney pathology scoring software) disseminated on NIDDK or collaborator websites.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Drug Abuse

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Secondary analysis of de-identified data from completed NIDA Clinical Trials Network (CTN) studies on substance use interventions.

lifecycle_curation.notes: An electronic data repository designed to share de-identified data from NIDA-funded clinical trials and studies. Access is open and free; investigators download data after agreeing to terms.

identity.resource_name: National Addiction & HIV Data Archive Program (NAHDAP)
identity.ic_name: National Institute on Drug Abuse

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Curating and distributing social/behavioral science datasets related to drug use, addiction, and HIV risk for research or teaching purposes.

lifecycle_curation.notes: A data archive at ICPSR sponsored by NIDA. All NAHDAP datasets are free to download for research or teaching; users register an ICPSR account (free for members).

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Drug Abuse

target_populations: Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development (ABCD) Study Cohort

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Tracking brain and behavior development in adolescents; analyzing the impact of substance use on youth development using the ABCD Study data.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIDA contributes substantially to NDA, notably the ABCD Study data. All ABCD data are shared via NDA portal for free after request approval.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Drug Abuse

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Discovering drug-abuse-related data (like optogenetics experiments) and other neuroscience resources and tools across various domains.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Initially funded by NIDA, NIF (now part of SciCrunch) is a dynamic search engine for neuroscience data and resources. The platform is open and free to use; indexed resources are linked for direct access.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Drug Abuse

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing genetic data (e.g., GWAS of opioid addiction) and transcriptomic analyses of drug-exposed brain tissue for secondary research.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIDA supports genetics studies of addiction; resulting data is deposited in repositories like dbGaP and NCBI GEO. Approved researchers can obtain these data without cost.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Drug Abuse

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Obtaining research-grade controlled substances (e.g., marijuana components, reference standards) that are otherwise restricted, for approved research studies.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIDA's Drug Supply Program provides certain controlled substances (for research) at no cost to investigators with DEA licenses for approved research studies.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Drug Abuse

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Using validated instruments (e.g., ASSIST) to screen patients for drug use or implementing evidence-based therapy protocols in clinical settings.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIDA has created free toolkits such as Standardized Screening Instruments (e.g., ASSIST) and therapy manuals for interventions (like motivational interviewing manuals), which are downloadable at no cost.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Drug Abuse

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Running simulations for drug epidemic spread (NetLogo), implementing standard neuroimaging tasks (fMRI), or using tools for data harmonization (Ontology).

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIDA-funded researchers developed tools like NetLogo models for simulations, fMRI task paradigms, and addiction Ontology tools, typically released as open-source or free downloads.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Detailing how environmental chemicals affect gene expression and contribute to diseases; analyzing mechanistic links between pollutants and health outcomes.

lifecycle_curation.notes: An NIEHS-funded public database that details chemical-gene-disease interactions. Completely open-access: anyone can search and export all data for free.

identity.resource_name: NIEHS Environmental Health Science Data Repositories
identity.ic_name: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Finding recommended NIH/external repositories (GEO, PubChem, ClinicalTrials.gov) where NIEHS-funded data have been deposited, ensuring compliance with data sharing policy.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIEHS maintains a list of recommended repositories and ensures data from its funded studies end up in these public domains. All linked resources are free for data access.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing data and publications related to environmental contamination and remediation activities at hazardous waste sites.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Provides access to data generated by Superfund Research Program grantees. The portal is open to the public, and there is no fee or restriction to obtain these data.

identity.resource_name: Environmental Factor and Exposure Data (HEALS, Toolbox)
identity.ic_name: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Querying combined exposure metrics (HEALS) or using GIS mapping tools (Exposure Science Toolbox) for fish consumption advisories and other exposure factors.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Includes the Exposure Science Toolbox (free GIS mapping tools) and the HEALS database (linking exposure and health effect data). Offered as free downloads or interactive tools.

identity.resource_name: Epidemiological Cohort Data (Sister Study, Ag Health Study)
identity.ic_name: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Requesting de-identified data from large cohorts (e.g., Sister Study) to investigate gene-environment interactions and long-term health outcomes.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Data from major NIEHS cohort studies (e.g., Sister Study, Agricultural Health Study) are available to external researchers. NIEHS does not charge for data access, though a formal request process is required.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing curated literature (Literature Portal) on climate change impacts or utilizing risk assessment tools (BRACE framework) for health planning.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Contributes to climate and health research by developing free tools like the Climate Change and Human Health Literature Portal and supporting the BRACE framework (with CDC), which includes free risk assessment tools.

identity.resource_name: Training and Analysis Resources (Omics, Ontology, Code)
identity.ic_name: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Using harmonized Omics protocols, ontology tools (EHLCC) to standardize terminology, and GitHub code repositories for analyzing environmental health data.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Provides free resources such as Harmonized Omics protocols and Environmental Health Language Collaborative's (EHLCC) ontology tools. These are open-source and free to use.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Downloading high-throughput screening data (Tox21) on thousands of chemicals to predict potential human health effects and risks.

lifecycle_curation.notes: High-throughput screening data generated via the Tox21 collaboration. Assay results are made available via PubChem and the EPA's ToxCast databases for free.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Searching for and downloading 3D structures of proteins and nucleic acids for research, analysis, and drug design.

lifecycle_curation.notes: A cornerstone resource for structural biology. All data are free; users download structures without login or payment. Provides free visualization/analysis tools.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Querying how genetic variation affects drug response, retrieving curated gene-drug associations, and accessing dosing guidelines.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Curated knowledgebase on how genetic variation affects drug response. Openly accessible; users query the website or download data files for free.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Obtaining cell lines and DNA from individuals with genetic disorders for research into rare diseases and genetic mechanisms.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Repository of cell lines (and DNA) from individuals with genetic disorders. Academic/nonprofit investigators receive cell lines for just a nominal handling fee (sometimes waived) or shipping.

identity.resource_name: NIGMS Biomedical Technology and Data Repositories
identity.ic_name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing comprehensive protein sequence databases (UniProt mirrors) and utilizing molecular dynamics simulation packages (CHARMM/AMBER) for computational modeling.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Funds domain-specific databases (e.g., UniProt US mirrors) and open-source Molecular Dynamics simulation packages (e.g., CHARMM, AMBER) for computational research.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing genetic and genomic data on common model species (FlyBase, WormBase) to inform research on general biological processes.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Supports MODs such as FlyBase (Drosophila) and WormBase (C. elegans). These databases are entirely free to access and provide genetic and genomic data on model species.

identity.resource_name: NIGMS Human Genetic Databases (OMIM, Alliance of Genome Resources)
identity.ic_name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing the Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man (OMIM) catalog for genetic diseases or exploring comparative genetics via the Alliance of Genome Resources.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Historically supported OMIM (Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man) and funds the Alliance of Genome Resources. OMIM remains free for users (with registration); Alliance is an open access comparative genetics initiative.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing chemical structures and bioassay data via PubChem, and querying protein-ligand binding affinities via BindingDB for drug discovery and modeling.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIGMS contributes to free resources like PubChem and funds BindingDB (a database of measured protein-ligand binding affinities). Both are open-access.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Performing molecular docking simulations (AutoDock) or visualizing complex biological network interactions (Cytoscape) in research.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIGMS supports computational modeling that yields free tools such as AutoDock (docking simulations) and Cytoscape (network biology visualization). These are open-source and free to download and use.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing and using tutorials on quantitative biology, chemical kinetics simulations, and other educational materials to improve biomedical education.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Makes training resources available for free, including tutorials on quantitative biology and simulations for teaching chemical kinetics, accessible for educators.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Mental Health

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing integrated, large-scale data (e.g., ABCD Study, NDAR) for research on the etiology, diagnosis, and treatment of mental illnesses.

lifecycle_curation.notes: A massive data repository housing research data from NIMH-funded studies, integrating NDAR and other databases. Data access is free; researchers apply for credentials and access to relevant datasets.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Mental Health

target_populations: Patients with Schizophrenia, Bipolar Disorder, Autism

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Obtaining well-characterized patient samples (DNA, cell lines) for schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and autism research to accelerate psychiatric genetics.

lifecycle_curation.notes: A biorepository offering DNA, cell lines, and other biomaterials from individuals with mental illnesses. No-cost distribution of samples; NIMH covers the cost of biospecimens.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Mental Health

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Obtaining post-mortem human brain tissue specimens for research on the underlying biology of psychiatric and neurodevelopmental disorders.

lifecycle_curation.notes: A network of brain tissue repositories providing post-mortem human brain specimens. Tissue requests are free (aside from shipping) to encourage research on brain disorders.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Mental Health

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Performing secondary analysis on data from large, completed NIMH clinical trials (e.g., STARD, CATIE) to study treatment efficacy and outcomes.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIMH ensures data from its large clinical trials (STARD, CATIE, STEP-BD) are shared. Datasets are available for download by qualified researchers at no cost (via NDA/NIH archives).

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Mental Health

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Adopting standard instruments (like PHQ-9 depression scale) and definitions in research protocols to ensure data consistency and comparability.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIMH CDEs for mental health domains (suicide, autism, depression scales). Instruments and definitions are available on the NIMH website or NIH CDE repository for free use.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Mental Health

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Using free templates and guidance (e.g., protocol templates, data management plans) to improve the quality and compliance of mental health research studies.

lifecycle_curation.notes: A collection of free templates and guidance documents for investigators (e.g., human subjects protection, DMPs). Accessible on the NIMH website without restriction or cost.

identity.resource_name: Software and Computational Resources (AFNI, Connectome Workbench)
identity.ic_name: National Institute of Mental Health

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Performing fMRI data analysis (AFNI) or visualizing connectome data (Connectome Workbench) for neuroscience research.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Produces tools like AFNI (Analysis of Functional NeuroImages)—MRI analysis software that is open-source and freely downloadable. Also supports Connectome Workbench.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Mental Health

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing free e-learning resources on research design and statistical methods to improve rigor in mental health studies.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Offers free e-learning resources on research design and statistical methods (like the 'Research Methods Resources' online). Available without cost or login.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing and visualizing health disparity statistics by race/ethnicity, geography, and socio-demographics; identifying evidence-based interventions to address disparities.

lifecycle_curation.notes: A NIMHD-developed web portal providing data (Data Portal) and tools for exploring minority health and health disparities. All features are free with no login required.

identity.resource_name: NIMHD Minority Health Research Framework Tool
identity.ic_name: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Designing studies that address multi-level disparity factors (biological, behavioral, socio-cultural, environmental, health system) using a standardized framework.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Provides a conceptual framework for factors influencing health disparities. Aims to provide tools (e.g., measures catalogue) to help investigators design multi-level disparity studies.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing and compiling public data (CDC, Census) to analyze health behaviors and socioeconomic factors in minority communities; finding data on small minority populations.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIMHD partners with agencies to make disparity data accessible. NIMHD often compiles such data into chartbooks or infographics for researchers, downloadable for free.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Utilizing tools (e.g., Neighborhood Social Vulnerability Index) or data dashboards developed by NIMHD-funded Centers of Excellence to study local health disparities.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Centers of Excellence develop toolkits and data resources (e.g., Neighborhood Social Vulnerability Index tool) that are shared publicly online through NIMHD or center websites.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Searching for evidence-based interventions by topic or minority population to address specific health disparities in community settings.

lifecycle_curation.notes: The HDPulse Intervention Portal is a repository of disparity-intervention programs. Users can search interventions and find descriptions/materials. It is freely available to translate research into practice.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Downloading and using free cultural competency training tools and health disparity science curricula (e.g., Unconscious Bias modules) in academic and research settings.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Provides free cultural competency training tools and health disparity science curricula (e.g., Unconscious Bias training module). These are free to download and use in academic settings.

identity.ic_name: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Compiling and accessing NIH multilingual health resources (e.g., Spanish-language materials) for use with non-English-speaking populations and community outreach.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Compiles multilingual health resources from NIH (like Spanish-language health materials) on its site. These are free for community health workers and researchers focusing on non-English-speaking populations.

identity.resource_name: FITBIR (Federal Interagency Traumatic Brain Injury Research informatics system)
identity.ic_name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Querying and downloading de-identified patient-level data (neuroimaging, outcomes) from multiple TBI studies in a harmonized format for pooled analysis.

lifecycle_curation.notes: A collaborative data repository for TBI studies. Researchers can request an account to query and download de-identified data. There are no fees to use the system or obtain data.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Obtaining post-mortem human brain tissue specimens for research on the underlying biology of neurological disorders (e.g., Parkinson's, ALS, epilepsy).

lifecycle_curation.notes: NINDS is a major participant in the NeuroBioBank. Provides post-mortem human brain tissue for neurological disorders. Tissue requests are free (aside from shipping).

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Adopting standardized data definitions and forms (CRFs) for neurological studies (stroke, epilepsy, TBI) to ensure data compatibility and increase research efficiency.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NINDS leads the development of CDEs for many neurological diseases. The CDE website provides data dictionaries and CRFs—all freely downloadable. Open-access resource that increases research efficiency at zero cost.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Obtaining DNA and cell lines from patients with neurological diseases (e.g., Huntington's, Parkinson's) to advance genetic research.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NINDS facilitates sharing of DNA, cell lines, and clinical data via its own program (e.g., ALS Biorepository) and the Coriell Cell Repositories. Samples are provided free or at nominal cost.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing de-identified clinical, imaging, and bio-sample metadata from the Parkinson's Disease Biomarkers Program (PDBP) for secondary analysis and biomarker discovery.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NINDS shares data from its clinical trials and biomarker studies (e.g., PDBP). Data are available to qualified researchers through a web portal without cost (registration and approval required).

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Downloading and utilizing free, open-source software tools and test datasets for MRI, EEG, and other neuroimaging data analysis.

lifecycle_curation.notes: A repository of neuroimaging analysis software, toolsets, and databases. Hosts hundreds of free, open-source tools and datasets. Users download software and data without charge.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing the free online Clinical Trials Methods course or obtaining common metrics (e.g., NIH Stroke Scale materials) for clinical study design and outcome measurement.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Offers free resources like the Clinical Trials Methods course online and common metrics for outcome measures (e.g., NIH Stroke Scale materials). Obtainable from NINDS websites at no cost.

identity.resource_name: NINR Data Sharing and Archive (via NIH Repositories)
identity.ic_name: National Institute of Nursing Research

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing nursing research data (genomic, behavioral) deposited in NIH-wide platforms like dbGaP, NDA, or NICHD DASH for secondary analysis.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NINR does not maintain a standalone repository but encourages grantees to use NIH repositories (dbGaP, NDA, DASH). All are accessible at no cost.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Nursing Research

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing de-identified intramural study data (e.g., symptom cluster trials) for secondary analysis in symptom science research.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NINR's focus on symptom science (pain, fatigue) leads to data sharing. De-identified data from intramural studies are shared via NIH repositories or by request at no charge.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Nursing Research

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Selecting and administering PROMIS item banks and short forms for symptom and function assessment.

lifecycle_curation.notes: PROMIS instruments are distributed through HealthMeasures; free registration provides scoring manuals and access to Assessment Center tools.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Nursing Research

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Using standardized cognition, motor, sensory, and emotional health measures across the lifespan.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NIH Toolbox instruments are delivered through HealthMeasures and require a free account for administration and scoring guidance.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Nursing Research

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing guidelines, competencies, and toolkits (e.g., 'Conversations Matter') to improve end-of-life care and obtain trial data for secondary analysis.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NINR provides free resources such as 'Peaceful Death: Recommended Competencies and Guidelines' and 'Palliative Care: Conversations Matter' toolkits. Trial data are expected to be shared via NIH repositories, making them freely available.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Nursing Research

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Locating and using measurement tools (e.g., caregiving burden scales) published by NINR-funded studies for reuse in new research protocols.

lifecycle_curation.notes: No formal NINR library, but NINR encourages investigators to publish their measurement tools (surveys for self-management, caregiving burden scales) on project websites or in publications, making them available at no cost.

identity.ic_name: National Institute of Nursing Research

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing training webinars and compiled psychosocial variable data from NINR-funded Centers for use in research or training programs.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NINR funds Centers that often produce community resources, such as training webinars and data repositories of psychosocial variables, which are shared freely.

identity.resource_name: Clinical Repositories (All of Us Research Program)
identity.ic_name: National Institute of Nursing Research

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Leveraging large-scale, diverse EHR and genomic data from the All of Us Research Program for inclusive population health and precision medicine studies.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NINR co-funds the All of Us Research Program (for inclusive population health data). All of Us data are available via a tiered access system for free to researchers.

identity.ic_name: National Library of Medicine

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Searching and accessing over 34 million citations and abstracts from MEDLINE and other biomedical sources.

lifecycle_curation.notes: The premier database of biomedical literature. Completely free to use; anyone can search without registration, and NLM's Entrez system allows programmatic access via API at no cost.

identity.ic_name: National Library of Medicine

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing and reading full-text biomedical articles, including all NIH-funded research articles (after 12 months), for research and public dissemination.

lifecycle_curation.notes: A free full-text digital archive of biomedical and life sciences journal literature. Open and free: users can read, download, and text-mine all articles in PMC.

identity.ic_name: National Library of Medicine

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Searching for information on clinical studies globally, tracking trial progress, and downloading posted study results and outcome data.

lifecycle_curation.notes: The public registry and results database of clinical studies (~450,000 trials globally). Free to search and access; study results can be viewed and downloaded at no cost.

identity.resource_name: NCBI Databases and Tools (GenBank, SRA, BLAST, dbGaP, PubChem, GEO)
identity.ic_name: National Library of Medicine

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Searching sequences (BLAST), accessing genomic data (GenBank), downloading raw sequencing reads (SRA), and obtaining controlled-access genetic data (dbGaP).

lifecycle_curation.notes: NLM's National Center for Biotechnology Information provides a vast array of molecular biology databases and tools (GenBank, SRA, dbGaP, PubChem, BLAST, GEO), all freely accessible.

identity.ic_name: National Library of Medicine

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Using NLM's controlled vocabulary for indexing articles in PubMed/MEDLINE, enhancing literature searches, and organizing information.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NLM's controlled vocabulary thesaurus used for indexing articles. Freely available: downloadable from NLM's website and searchable via the MeSH browser. No licensing fee (public domain).

identity.ic_name: National Library of Medicine

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Linking and mapping various biomedical vocabularies (SNOMED, MeSH, ICD) to support NLP, data standardization, and complex information retrieval applications.

lifecycle_curation.notes: A large compendium of biomedical terminology mappings. NLM makes UMLS available for free, though users must sign a license agreement online (no charge).

identity.ic_name: National Library of Medicine

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Providing consumer-friendly, reliable information on diseases, conditions, and drugs to the public and patients.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NLM's consumer health information portal. Summarizes diseases, conditions, and drugs in lay language. It has no cost and no login for use.

identity.ic_name: National Library of Medicine

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Reading medical textbooks, reference works, and official NIH clinical guidelines online at no charge.

lifecycle_curation.notes: A full-text repository of biomedical books, reports, and guidelines provided online free. Researchers can read textbooks or reference works at no charge.

identity.ic_name: National Library of Medicine

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing chemical toxicity and hazardous substance data, now primarily through PubChem and other specialized NLM data portals.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NLM's former toxicology data network. Content (e.g., ChemIDplus, LactMed) was integrated into PubChem or other free resources. The toxicity data remains free.

identity.resource_name: Open Source Software and APIs (E-utilities, ClinicalTrials.gov API)
identity.ic_name: National Library of Medicine

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Programmatically retrieving and incorporating data from NCBI, PubMed, and ClinicalTrials.gov into automated workflows and applications.

lifecycle_curation.notes: NLM develops tools like the NCBI C++ Toolkit, Entrez Direct (command line tools), and the ClinicalTrials.gov API, which are all open-source or open-access and usable without any cost.

identity.resource_name: Clinical Center Clinical Data (e.g., Chest X-ray8)
identity.ic_name: NIH Clinical Center

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Utilizing the Chest X-ray8 image dataset and other specific collections for machine learning research and algorithm development.

lifecycle_curation.notes: The NIH Clinical Center releases de-identified datasets, such as the Chest X-ray8 image dataset (over 100,000 images), to open archives for research training purposes, all freely downloadable.

identity.ic_name: NIH Clinical Center

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing the Biowulf supercomputing cluster for advanced data analysis (genomic analysis, imaging) related to Clinical Center protocols, provided at no cost to external collaborators.

lifecycle_curation.notes: The Biowulf supercomputing cluster is a free resource for NIH intramural staff. External collaborators on CC protocols often get access for data analysis without charge.

identity.ic_name: NIH Clinical Center

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing the Introduction to the Principles and Practice of Clinical Research (IPPCR) course online to gain foundational knowledge in study design and ethics.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Provides free training courses open to researchers globally, notably the Introduction to the Principles and Practice of Clinical Research (IPPCR) course. It is free of charge; participants access video lectures and materials via the CC website.

identity.resource_name: Protocol Templates and Data Collection Forms
identity.ic_name: NIH Clinical Center

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Using NIH best-practice templates for designing studies, drafting informed consent documents, and preparing case report forms (CRFs).

lifecycle_curation.notes: The Clinical Center shares various protocol templates, informed consent templates, and case report forms it uses, as models for others. These are available freely on the CC or NIH Office of Clinical Research websites.

identity.ic_name: NIH Clinical Center

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Utilizing CC-curated datasets (e.g., a planned COVID-19 dataset) for AI training and model development in medical research, provided without fees.

lifecycle_curation.notes: The CC was exploring making more of its data public (e.g., planned COVID-19 dataset). Any CC-curated datasets would be made available via NIH-controlled repositories without fees.

identity.ic_name: NIH Clinical Center

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing de-identified imaging datasets (e.g., PET/CT for tumor segmentation, BRATS challenge data) to participate in public challenges and develop AI models.

lifecycle_curation.notes: The CC hosts or contributes to public challenges (e.g., PET/CT image datasets, BRATS challenge data). Data are anonymized and shared openly with the research community at no cost.

identity.ic_name: NIH Clinical Center

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Using the synthetic dataset for the Biomedical Translational Research Information System (BTRIS) to allow external developers to test queries and build research applications.

lifecycle_curation.notes: The CC publishes lessons and open-source components, such as a synthetic dataset for BTRIS to allow external developers to test queries. This synthetic data is free to access for anyone building research applications.

identity.ic_name: NIH Clinical Center

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing the archives of the Clinical Center Grand Rounds presentations (webcast publicly) and open-access journal content for professional development and education.

lifecycle_curation.notes: The Clinical Center Grand Rounds presentations are publicly webcast and archived; they serve as an educational resource available freely to clinicians and researchers everywhere.

identity.ic_name: Center for Information Technology

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Running large-scale genomic analyses, complex image processing, and AI modeling tasks that require significant computational power.

lifecycle_curation.notes: CIT operates Biowulf, a high-performance computing cluster. It is a free resource for those eligible (NIH intramural researchers and their collaborators) as they do not pay for computing time or storage.

identity.ic_name: Center for Information Technology

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing subsidized commercial cloud computing services (Google/AWS) for data storage and analysis of large NIH-funded datasets (e.g., TOPMed, All of Us).

lifecycle_curation.notes: CIT partners in NIH's STRIDES initiative, offering subsidized cloud computing with commercial providers for NIH-funded projects. Provides free credits or pilot cloud resources to reduce or eliminate initial cost.

identity.ic_name: Center for Information Technology

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Searching and downloading standardized data definitions (CDEs) from various institutes (e.g., NINDS, NIMH) to ensure consistent data collection across studies.

lifecycle_curation.notes: CIT hosts the NIH CDE Repository in partnership with NLM. It houses standardized data definitions from multiple institutes and is open-access; anyone can search and download CDE forms for free.

identity.ic_name: Center for Information Technology

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing the NIH VideoCast archive to watch past seminars, meetings, and major events (e.g., Wednesday Afternoon Lecture Series) for free education and information.

lifecycle_curation.notes: CIT provides the NIH VideoCast system, which streams and archives NIH seminars and conferences. The archives are open to the public at no cost.

identity.ic_name: Center for Information Technology

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Utilizing open-source tools like ImageJ (NIH Image) for image analysis or accessing utility software released by CIT on GitHub for data management.

lifecycle_curation.notes: CIT develops/supports open-source software like ImageJ (NIH Image) as a free image analysis tool (public domain). It also releases various utility software on GitHub under open licenses.

identity.ic_name: Center for Information Technology

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Securely transmitting sensitive data (SEMS) and large files (ASPERA) between NIH researchers and outside academic partners, with costs covered by NIH.

lifecycle_curation.notes: CIT's Secure Email (SEMS) and Secure File Transfer (ASPERA) are used to send sensitive data to outside collaborators. The service is provided at no cost to the partner to facilitate secure exchange.

identity.ic_name: Center for Information Technology

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Using ASSIST to prepare and submit NIH grant applications electronically and using Commons to manage the grant lifecycle (status, reporting).

lifecycle_curation.notes: Systems for grant submission (ASSIST) and managing grants (Commons) are supported by CIT. These tools are provided freely for the external researcher community applying for NIH funding.

identity.resource_name: Cloud-based Data Repositories (NIH Figshare/Science Data Portal)
identity.ic_name: Center for Information Technology

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing datasets and materials posted by NIH intramural scientists on general data repositories like NIH Figshare or via Science Data Portal prototypes.

lifecycle_curation.notes: CIT is involved in hosting platforms like NIH Figshare (a general data repository for NIH preprints and materials) and Science Data Portal prototypes. These would allow free public access to deposited datasets.

identity.ic_name: Center for Information Technology

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Accessing the extensive, publicly available Biowulf User Guide and code recipes for bioinformatics to learn and implement analysis workflows.

lifecycle_curation.notes: Shares best practices and code through NIH Tech Talks (often videocast publicly) and maintains extensive, freely available documentation (e.g., the Biowulf User Guide and code recipes for bioinformatics).

identity.ic_name: Center for Scientific Review

practical_usage.typical_use_cases: Studying successful grant proposals (R01, R21) and reviewers' critiques to understand review expectations and improve application quality.

lifecycle_curation.notes: CSR provides valuable resources to help researchers craft strong applications. Sample funded grant applications and summary statements are made available for educational purposes, which are freely downloadable.
